item.title: Topic 3: Logic
item.description: A basic organizing structure for philosophy is the argument. Arguments are sets of statements where one of the statements is a conclusion. What knits them together is logic. We will think about what arguments are and then learn some basic ideas of logic. Reading “Basic Ideas and Tools,” Chapter 1 of A Modem Formal Logic Primer by Edmund Teller, sections 1-1 to 1-4, or equivalently pages 1–10 of Volume 1.

item.title: Topic 2: Determinism and Freedom
item.description: This brief topic offers a basic philosophical problem with a very long history. It’s an interesting problem, but we’re also starting with it to get a first look at philosophical methodology and the structure of arguments and counter-arguments. Reading Daniel Dennett, Elbow Room: The Varieties of Free Will Worth Wanting (1984), 2 brief excerpts, 4 pages (Blackboard) See also In the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy: Causal Determinism Free Will Compatibilism Skepticism about Moral Responsibility Entertaining movies on this topic include [Memento][https://www.

item.title: Topic 1: What Is Philosophy?
item.description: Prominent philosopher Martha Nussbaum was recently asked “How would you define the role of a philosopher in today’s world?” She answered: I wouldn’t. There are so many good ways to engage with the world, and each philosopher should figure it out for herself. I don’t like telling others what to do. Still, philosophy has a history. And its history involves people doing specific things and calling them “philosophy,” and not calling other things “philosophy.
